definitions: The rate at which velocity changes over time.
Change in speed and/or direction per unit time.
A vector quantity describing how quickly an object’s velocity increases or decreases.
In linear motion, how fast velocity (m/s) changes each second (m/s²).
The muscle primarily responsible for producing a specific movement.
The main muscle generating force for a given joint action.
The prime mover that contributes the greatest torque for a movement.
The muscle whose contraction is the primary driver of the desired motion.
Standard reference posture: standing upright, facing forward, arms at sides, palms forward.
Baseline body orientation used to describe locations and movements consistently.
Reference position for anatomical terms (anterior/posterior, medial/lateral, etc.).
Body standing erect with feet forward and forearms supinated (palms forward).

The change in angular position of a joint or body segment.
How far something rotates, measured in degrees or radians.
Difference between initial and final angular position about an axis.
Rotational equivalent of linear displacement.
The rate of change of angular displacement over time.
How fast an object rotates about an axis (deg/s or rad/s).

Application of physics to human movement and living structures.

Back-facing orientation (e.g., dorsal surface).

Opposition to changes in velocity (speed or direction).

Closer to the trunk or point of attachment.
